body_content.explanation: a part of an activity or a period of development:
examples: The project is in its final stages and should be completed by August.
They did the last stage of their journey on foot.
Our marriage is going through a difficult stage at the moment.
Their youngest child is at the stage where she can say individual words but not full sentences.
I'm not tired at the moment but I will need a rest at some stage (= at some time) during the walk.
Andrew spends all his spare time playing with his computer but it's probably just a stage he's going through (= a period of development that will end soon).

body_content.explanation: If you do something in stages, you divide the activity into parts and complete each part separately:
examples: We're decorating the house in stages so it won't be ready for another couple of months.

body_content.explanation: one of the separate parts of a rocket, each part having its own engine:
examples: Once its fuel supply runs out, each stage separates from the main part of the rocket and falls back to earth.

body_content.explanation: the area in a theatre that is often raised above ground level and on which actors or entertainers perform:
examples: Hamlet is on stage for most of the act.
The orchestra went on/off stage to great applause.
The play is a stage adaptation of William Golding's novel.
The singer returns to the Oslo stage (= will perform again in Oslo) this summer.

body_content.explanation: a particular area of public life:
examples: The president was extremely popular on the world stage but was disliked in his own country.

body_content.explanation: to go onto the stage and start to perform:
examples: She was waiting to take the stage at a rally in Ohio.

body_content.explanation: to arrange and perform a play or show:
examples: The local drama group is staging a production of the musical "Grease".
London staged the Olympic Games in 2012.
